oh you want to go multidex?
I want to replicate the error and see how our app behaves w/ multidex
so basically grab a bunch of libs and force a bunch of them in the 1st dexfile

compile "org.scala-lang:scala-library:2.11.7"

Hi :slightly_smiling_face:
(The goal is simply to get a handler not on the main thread)
that is ‘the’ way to do it
Can I ask why you want a handler thread though? Why not just use an executor service?
Hi thanks for your answer
I've got an ImageReader, and I wish for it to run on a separate thread (since it's gonna do some computing with Bitmap, etc)
And it takes a handler in parameter
makes sense
`imageReader.setOnImageAvailableListener(new onImageAvailableListener(), handler);`
I found the way I described above to get a separate handler, but I just wanted to know if there was a better or simpler way !
that’s the way just be aware if you are creating a thread every time that you have to call quit() on it. Alternately you can just keep one instance of the thread forever
My class will keep its reference to the handlerthread, until it is destroyed
btw, if I just cease to use my class, without calling handlerthread.quitSafely, it will lead to memory leaks ?
no, it’s not a memory leak it is a resource leak
oh ok

You’ll have a thread that is stuck waiting for work that you can never reference again. It’s not a huge deal but you don’t want to keep around idle threads. I would recommend you create the thread once and just keep it around unless you really need multiple instances to do parallel work
well the imagereader is created at will along with a foreground service, so a handlerthread is created each time the service is shutdown and re-started
but I could make a handlerthread somewhere else, and get it via injection (or static method) and always use the same one
correct
is it the way to go ?
that’s what I would do
like make a singleton 'imagereaderthread' or something
yes unless you are using dagger then obviously you should have dagger provide it
but it means it would be instanciated even if the user doesn't use the service
yes but that’s not an issue because it will just sit waiting
I am using Dagger2
ok then
the issue I was describing was endlessly creating threads and never killing them
yeah ok
with dagger2, I just have to make a provideHandlerthread singleton ?
(I'm very new to DI)
you just use the @Singleton annotation
Or is it better to make a custom class
nothing wrong with what you have there
<@U3MGKGRP1|edisseus> has joined the channel
OK thanks :slightly_smiling_face: the only downside I see, is that I can only have one handlerthread that way

<@U3E2EEX38> the key difference in relays is that they don't die on terminal events (read: onError)

well at least in my senario anyway
I just send a String and if anyone wants to listen they can
there is no error
the subscriber can implement error
but the actual Publish subject doesnt care
If you do Rx Properly you shouldnt need a relay

JakeWharton commented on 12 Apr 2016
A subject is an escape hatch in/out of a stream for non-reactive code. As more of your code becomes reactive (i.e., represented as observables) then you don't need these escape hatches, and can instead use the built-in primitives (like flatMap, etc.) to compose things together.
Relays are mutable, which is why they should be avoided where possible.
I think in most use-cases, you need to share state via a BehaviorRelay
this whole "hur dur mutable state is bad" seems to avoid the issue that you *need to be able to persist the state to a bundle*
<@U3E2EEX38> you can't just throw away the application state when you go into background, that is not "pure", that is just stupid

<@U39P7U6EP> I don't get it, I don't think we should be using Publishsubjects for important things that need to be restored on state change, they are instead used for example as an event bus. The Observer pattern is used to observe the change of state of objects, saving the state and restoring them has little effect on the Observer and and object that is being watched or observed is the the subject and can maintain its own state. In the end all a PublishSubject is, is an Observer and Subscriber in one, anyway. If you restore the state of objects, then the Observers will just continue observing from that point, so nothing its lost.

Also if you need to, you can resubscribe to observables using RxJava's built-in caching mechanisms, you can unsubscribe/resubscribe to the same Observable,  In particular, cache() (or replay()) will continue the underlying request (even if you unsubscribe). That means you can resume with a new subscription after Activity recreation
but of course you have to save the Observable

text: <@U3MP7KME3|arimeidan> has joined the channel

I want to work on this kind of structure , where addForm would only give setCampaignName function not any other , so untill I have campaign name no other function can be accessed, what could be the best way to do this ?
I’d say addForm would return a different type than setCampaignName. That way you can limit what is called on each
<@U0LFEJ1ST> make it a parameter in `addForm(String campaignName)` thus you'll get compilation error and wont be able to continue if no CampaignName added.
